revision.text:
{{redirect-distinguish|Hockeyville|Hockeytown}} {{short description|Community competition in ice hockey}} {{Use Canadian English|date=May 2015}} {{More citations needed|section|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Kraft Hockeyville | image = KraftHockeyville.png | caption = Kraft Hockeyville logo | country = Canada (2006-present)
United States (2015-present) | language = English | creator = Tony Chapman
Fred Nicolaidis
Pamela McNair
Harry Doupe | num_seasons = 13 | runtime = 44 minutes (2006)
5 minutes (2007–present) | network = [[CBC Television]]/[[Sportsnet]] (Canada, 2006–present)
[[NBC]]/[[NBCSN]] (United States, 2015–present) | first_aired = 2006 | last_aired = present | website_title = Kraft Hockeyville Canada | website = https://www.krafthockeyville.ca/ | production_website_title = Kraft Hockeyville USA | production_website = https://www.krafthockeyville.com/ }} '''''Kraft Hockeyville''''' is an annual competition sponsored by [[Kraft Heinz]], the [[National Hockey League]] and the [[NHL Players' Association]] in which communities compete to demonstrate their commitment to the sport of [[ice hockey]]. The winning community gets a cash prize dedicated to upgrading their local home arena, as well as the opportunity to host an NHL pre-season game. Runners-up also get smaller cash prizes to upgrade their ice rinks. The contest is normally held in the winter and spring during the latter half of the NHL regular season, with the pre-season game usually held in September before the following regular season. If the winning arena is not adequately equipped to host the pre-season game, it is then played at an alternative site nearby. The idea and theme was developed by Capital C, a Canadian Advertising Agency that was founded by Tony Chapman. The contest itself was developed by Fred Nicolaidis, Pamela McNair, and Harry Doupe of the CBC. The competition was first held across Canada in 2006 as a [[reality television]] series aired by [[CBC Television]], but since 2007, it has been relegated to segments aired during CBC's ''[[Hockey Night in Canada]]''. Kraft expanded the event in 2015 to the United States, with segments of the US contest are aired on the ''[[NHL on NBC]]''. The Kraft Hockeyville games are televised regionally, in their respective countries on national basis. From 2006 to 2014, the Canadian game was broadcast across Canada on CBC, while [[Sportsnet]] took over airing it in 2015. The United States game is televised nationally in the U.S. on [[NBCSN]]. ==Rules== Communities are invited to submit their nominations. The application form also requires a short essay, and photographs or a video, depicting the community's hometown pride and passion for the game of hockey. A judging panel then selects four finalists. The winner is then determined by a public vote.{{cite web | url=https://kraft.promo.eprize.com/hockeyville2018/public/share/fulfillment/rules_ca.pdf | title=Karft Hockeyville Canada rules | accessdate=January 27, 2018}}{{cite web | url=https://kraft.promo.eprize.com/hockeyville2018/public/share/fulfillment/rules.pdf | title=Karft Hockeyville USA rules | accessdate=January 27, 2018}} ==History== ===2006 season=== The inaugural 2006 season of ''Hockeyville'' featured finalists Smithers, British Columbia, Falher and Airdrie, Alberta, Barry's Bay, Ontario, and as its very first champion, the community of [[Salmon River, Colchester County (community)|Salmon River]], [[Nova Scotia]]. Salmon River's entry, the "Deuvilles Rink", beat 450 other entries from across Canada. The initial four episodes for the 2006 season were shot at the Memorial Centre in Kingston, Ontario, with the final three episodes shot in [[Dave Andreychuk Mountain Arena & Skating Centre]] in [[Hamilton, Ontario]]. The NHL exhibition game was held September 25 at the [[Colchester Legion Stadium]] in the neighbouring town of [[Truro, Nova Scotia|Truro]] (the Deuville Rink being too small); the [[Montreal Canadiens]] beat the [[Ottawa Senators]] 7-3. *The Deuville rink was awarded the C$50,000 Home Depot gift card prize and with the cards the roof was reshingled, new rink lights were installed, ceiling insulated and a heated section was installed at the end of the arena. ===2007 season=== The 2007 season of ''Hockeyville'' began on March 4 and was changed significantly from the previous season's format. Organizers made the application process more accessible. Communities could now enter by logging on to the website, creating a team name, filling out an application form, submitting a short essay and including three photographs which depict hometown pride and passion for the game of hockey. A video, which was a requirement in previous contests, is no longer part of the process. In 2007 the series was no longer given its own time slot, but rather shown during broadcasts of [[Hockey Night in Canada]]. The Top 10 communities resulting from the first round were [[Cornwall, Ontario]]; [[Nanaimo, British Columbia]]; [[Noëlville, Ontario]]; [[North Bay, Ontario]]; [[Plaster Rock, New Brunswick]]; [[Rockyford, Alberta]]; [[Saint-Hubert, Quebec]]; [[Smithers, British Columbia]]; [[Vernon, British Columbia]] and [[Warner, Alberta]]. The Top 5 communities resulting from the second round were Cornwall, Noëlville, North Bay, Smithers and Warner. North Bay was the winner. The [[Atlanta Thrashers]] beat the [[New York Islanders]] 4-3 in overtime. ===2008 season=== The 2008 season of ''Kraft Hockeyville'' began February 23. The top 10 communities that were in the running for Kraft Hockeyville 2008 were: * '''East''': [[Channel – Port aux Basques|Port aux Basques, Newfoundland and Labrador]] vs. [[Rothesay, New Brunswick]] * '''West''': [[Wilcox, Saskatchewan]] vs. [[Redwater, Alberta]] * '''Quebec''': [[Rouyn-Noranda]] vs. Village sur Glace de [[Roberval, Quebec|Roberval]] * '''Ontario''': [[Huntsville, Ontario|Huntsville]] vs. [[Kingsville, Ontario|Kingsville]] * '''Wildcard''': [[Winnipegosis, Manitoba]] vs. [[Pilot Mound, Manitoba]] The top 5 communities were: *'''Week 1:''' Village sur Glace de [[Roberval, Quebec|Roberval]] (Quebec Region) *'''Week 2:''' [[Channel – Port aux Basques|Port aux Basques, Newfoundland and Labrador]] (Atlantic Region) *'''Week 3:''' [[Kingsville, Ontario]] (Ontario Region) *'''Week 4:''' [[Wilcox, Saskatchewan]] (Western Region) *'''Week 5:''' [[Pilot Mound, Manitoba]] (Wildcard) On April 8, 2008, Roberval won the title of Kraft Hockeyville 2008. Roberval won: * C$100,000 towards upgrades to the Roberval Arena * An NHL pre-season game at the Roberval Arena on Tuesday, September 23, 2008 in which the [[Montreal Canadiens]] defeated the [[Buffalo Sabres]] 3-2. * A ''[[Hockey Night in Canada]]'' broadcast from Roberval The pre-season game has been taped and shown on a ''Hockeyville'' special Saturday, September 27.[http://www.newswire.ca/en/releases/archive/April2008/09/c3802.html CNW Group | NEWS - MEDIA | Roberval, Quebec wins KRAFT HOCKEYVILLE 2008] The 4 remaining communities from the Top 5 won: * C$20,000 to be used for upgrades to the Home Arena that the community endorses * A ''[[Hockey Night in Canada]]'' broadcast from each of the remaining top five communities ===2009 season=== The 2009 edition had these cities as the five regional finalists: *'''Atlantic:''' [[Harbour Grace, Newfoundland and Labrador]] *'''Quebec:''' [[Thetford Mines|Thetford Mines, Quebec]] *'''Ontario:''' [[Woolwich, Ontario|Woolwich Township, Ontario]] *'''Western:''' [[Terrace, British Columbia]] *'''Wildcard:''' [[Humboldt, Saskatchewan]] The winner, announced on March 7 during the [[Hockey Night in Canada]] broadcast, was Terrace, British Columbia. Terrace played host to the [[Vancouver Canucks]] and the [[New York Islanders]] on Monday, September 14, in which the Canucks defeated the Islanders by a score of 2-1. The game was broadcast live on [[NHL Network (United States)|NHL Network]] in the US, and highlights were televised during a one-hour Kraft Hockeyville broadcast showcasing their community on CBC Television. Terrace also received C$100,000 towards arena upgrades from Kraft Canada. ===2010 season=== The five finalists for the 2010 edition of ''Hockeyville'' *'''Atlantic:''' [[Bishop's Falls, Newfoundland and Labrador]] *'''Quebec:''' [[Stanstead, Quebec]] *'''Ontario:''' [[Dundas, Ontario]] *'''Western:''' [[Cranbrook, British Columbia]] *'''Wildcard:''' [[Lawrencetown, Annapolis County, Nova Scotia|Lawrencetown, Nova Scotia]] Dundas, Ontario was announced as the winner by [[Gary Bettman]] on April 3, 2010, during the [[Hockey Night in Canada]] broadcast with 1,066,855 votes.{{cite web |url=http://www.thespec.com/News/article/747618|title=Dundas: Canada's Hockeyville|date=2010-04-04|publisher=TheSpec.com|accessdate=2010-06-09}} The game featured division rivals [[Buffalo Sabres]] and [[Ottawa Senators]] playing in Dundas's [[J. L. Grightmire Arena]] on September 28, 2010, with Buffalo winning 2-1.http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=538905 (Incidentally, Dundas has been, since 2000, within the boundaries of the city of [[Hamilton, Ontario]], a frequent target of efforts regarding [[potential National Hockey League expansion]].) ===2011 season=== In 2011, the wildcard was eliminated and the West and Pacific divisions were split from each other. The top 5 communities were: * '''Pacific''': [[Mackenzie, British Columbia]] * '''West''': [[Bentley, Alberta]] * '''Ontario''': [[Wolfe Island (Ontario)|Wolfe Island]] * '''Quebec''': [[Saint-Raymond, Quebec|Saint-Raymond]] * '''Atlantic''': [[Conception Bay South]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador]] Conception Bay South, NL, was declared the winner of Kraft Hockeyville 2011 on April 2, 2011. The town's arena received C$100,000 worth of renovations, and also was to host a pre-season game between the [[Ottawa Senators]] and the [[Atlanta Thrashers]] on September 26, 2011. However, with the purchase of the Thrashers and their re-location to Winnipeg as a revival of the [[Winnipeg Jets]], the game was instead played between the Senators and Jets. Additionally, the game was re-located to the [[Mile One Centre]] in [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]], 30 km north of Conception Bay South, which was the home arena of their newly relocated [[American Hockey League]] affiliate, the [[St. John's IceCaps]] (formerly the [[Manitoba Moose]]). The Jets defeated the Senators, 3–1.{{cite news |url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/hockey/globe-on-hockey/nhl-set-to-play-preseason-games-all-over-world/article2124179/ |title = NHL set to play preseason games all over world |work = The Globe and Mail |location = Toronto |access-date = August 15, 2011 }} Each of the other 4 finalists received C$25,000 in arena upgrades from Kraft. ===2012 season (Game played in 2013 season)=== [[Stirling-Rawdon]], [[Ontario]] was the winner of the 2012 Kraft Hockeyville contest. The planned game between the [[Columbus Blue Jackets]] and the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] on October 3{{cite web | url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=625275 | title=Stirling-Rawdon crowned Kraft Hockeyville | publisher=National Hockey League | date=March 31, 2012 | accessdate=May 2, 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://www.torontosun.com/2012/06/21/leafs-announced-2012-13-schedule | title=Leafs announce 2012-13 schedule | work=Toronto Sun | date=June 21, 2012 | accessdate=May 3, 2015}} was eventually cancelled due to the [[2012–13 NHL lockout]], but other festivities continued as scheduled. An NHL alumni charity game was held in the town instead, with one of the participants being Stirling native [[Rob Ray]]. No contest was held in 2013 due to the lockout.https://edmontonjournal.com/sports/hockey/calgary-flames/Kraft+cancels+Hockeyville+program+lockout/7583826/story.html A makeup game for the market was held in [[Belleville, Ontario]] on 2013 between the [[Washington Capitals]] and the [[Winnipeg Jets]].http://www.washingtontimes.com/blog/capitals-watch/2013/jun/27/capitals-face-blackhawks-bruins-twice-each-preseas/ ===2014 season=== The Top 16 towns for the Kraft Hockeyville contest were announced on Saturday, March 8. This year's contest has a theme much like the NHL itself: East VS West. This means there are 8 towns chosen from Eastern Canada and 8 towns from Western Canada.http://www.cbc.ca/sports/hockey/nhl/hockeyville-top-16-communites-announced-1.2565151 From Eastern Canada: * '''Richmond, ON''' * '''Prescott, ON''' * '''Beeton, ON''' * '''Exeter, ON''' * '''Chicoutimi, QC''' * '''Kingston, NS''' * '''Amherst, NS''' * '''Central Bedeque, PEI''' From Western Canada: * '''Salmon Arm, BC''' * '''Kimberly, BC''' * '''Osoyoos, BC''' * '''Bruderheim, AB''' * '''St. Albert, AB''' * '''Sylvan Lake, AB''' * '''Swift Current, SK''' * '''Arborg, MB''' This year, the top 16 towns are guaranteed C$25,000 in upgrades to their arenas instead of the top 5. Then the top 4 (two from the East and two from the West) received at least C$50,000. The winner receives the usual prize of C$100,000, an NHL pre-season game hosted in their community, and a visit from CBC's ''Hockey Night in Canada''. Voting for the top 16 ended on Monday, March 10.http://krafthockeyville.cbc.ca/ Sylvan Lake won the competition on April 7, and hosted a pre-season game between the [[Arizona Coyotes]] and the [[Calgary Flames]] on September 24. ===2015 season=== For the 2015 season, ''Kraft Hockeyville USA'', for the first time, drew candidates from the [[United States]]. The US finalist in the east was the [[Cambria County War Memorial Arena]] in [[Johnstown, Pennsylvania]], while the finalist in the west was the Decatur Civic Center in [[Decatur, Illinois]]. Johnstown was named the winner on May 2, received US$150,000 for arena upgrades, and hosted the [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] and the [[Pittsburgh Penguins]].{{cite web | url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=766175 | title=Johnstown, PA wins title of first-ever 'Kraft Hockeyville USA' | publisher=National Hockey League | date=May 2, 2015 | accessdate=May 2, 2015}} The game was televised in the United States on [[NBCSN]]. The Canadian Kraft Hockeyville finalist in the east was the [[Chatham Memorial Arena]] in [[Chatham, Ontario]], and the finalist in the west was the Panorama Recreation Center Hockey Arena in [[North Saanich, British Columbia]]. North Saanich was named the winner on April 5, and received C$100,000 in upgrades.{{cite web | url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=761490 | title=North Saanich, B.C. named Kraft Hockeyville 2015 | publisher=National Hockey League | date=April 5, 2015 | accessdate=May 2, 2015}} Because the Panorama Recreation Center Hockey Arena had a limited capacity of only 500, the pre-season game featuring the [[San Jose Sharks]] and the [[Vancouver Canucks]] was instead played at [[The Q Centre]] in nearby [[Colwood, British Columbia|Colwood]].{{cite web | url= http://www.timescolonist.com/sports/north-saanich-s-kraft-hockeyville-game-headed-to-the-q-centre-1.1980990 | title=North Saanich's Kraft Hockeyville game headed to The Q Centre | work=Times Colonist | date=June 25, 2015 | accessdate=September 20, 2015}} For the first time, the Hockeyville game was broadcast in Canada on [[Sportsnet]] instead of CBC. ===2016 season=== The Canadian Kraft Hockeyville finalist in the east was the Aréna St-Isidore in [[Saint-Isidore, Chaudière-Appalaches, Quebec]], and the finalist in the west was the Pat Duke Memorial Arena in [[Lumby, British Columbia]]. Lumby was named the winner on April 2, and received C$100,000 in upgrades.{{cite web | url=https://www.nhl.com/news/lumby-is-kraft-hockeyville/c-280085766 | title=Kraft Hockeyville chooses Lumby, British Columbia | publisher=National Hockey League | date=April 3, 2016 | accessdate=April 3, 2016}} Because the Pat Duke Memorial Arena had a limited seating capacity, the pre-season game featuring the [[Los Angeles Kings]] and the [[Edmonton Oilers]] on October 2 was instead played at [[Kal Tire Place]] in nearby [[Vernon, British Columbia|Vernon]].{{cite web | url= http://www.vernonmorningstar.com/news/388320701.html | title=Kal Tire Place will host Kraft Hockeyville NHL pre-season game Oct. 2| work=Vernon Morning Star | date=July 26, 2016 | accessdate=July 30, 2016}} The Kraft Hockeyville USA finalist in the east was the [[Lakeview Arena]] in [[Marquette, Michigan]], and the finalist in the west was the Rushmore Thunderdome in [[Rapid City, South Dakota]]. Marquette was named the winner on April 30, received US$150,000 in upgrades, and hosted the [[Carolina Hurricanes]] and the [[Buffalo Sabres]] on October 4.{{cite web | url=https://www.nhl.com/news/hockeyville-usa-2016-winner-is-marquette-mich/c-280524324 | title=Marquette, Mich., wins Kraft Hockeyville USA 2016 | publisher=National Hockey League | date=April 30, 2016 | accessdate=April 30, 2016}} ===2017 season=== The Canadian Kraft Hockeyville finalist in the east was the O'Leary Community Sports Centre in [[O'Leary, Prince Edward Island]], and the finalist in the west was the Ituna Skating Rink in [[Ituna, Saskatchewan]]. O'Leary was named the winner on April 2, 2017, and received C$100,000 in arena upgrades. Citing transportation and other issues with the O'Leary Community Sports Centre, the pre-season game between the [[New Jersey Devils]] and the [[Ottawa Senators]] on September 25, 2017, was instead played at the [[Consolidated Credit Union Place]] in nearby [[Summerside, Prince Edward Island|Summerside]].{{cite web | url= http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/prince-edward-island/pei-hockeyville-summerside-1.4166955 | title=Kraft Hockeyville game to be played in Summerside| publisher=CBC News | date=June 19, 2017 | accessdate=September 25, 2017}} The Kraft Hockeyville USA finalist in the east was the [[Rostraver Ice Garden]] in [[Belle Vernon, Pennsylvania]], and the finalist in the west was the Bloomington Ice Garden in [[Bloomington, Minnesota]]. Belle Vernon was named the winner on April 29, 2017, and received US$150,000 in arena upgrades. Because the Rostraver Ice Garden (despite being large by community arena standards and having hosted professional sports in the preceding decade) was deemed not fit to host a pre-season game, the contest between the [[St. Louis Blues]] and the [[Pittsburgh Penguins]] on September 24, 2017, was instead played the UPMC Lemieux Sports Complex in [[Cranberry Township, Butler County, Pennsylvania|Cranberry, Butler County]].{{cite web|last1=Rosenberg|first1=Matt|last2=Peirce|first2=Paul|title=Rostraver Ice Garden deemed unfit to host Penguins preseason game|url=http://triblive.com/sports/penguins/12577553-74/rostraver-ice-garden-deemed-unfit-to-host-penguins-preseason-game|website=Trib Live|accessdate=August 4, 2017|date=August 2, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Benderev|first1=Chris|title=Western Pa. Ice Rink Must Forgo Honor Of Hosting NHL Preseason Game|url=http://whqr.org/post/western-pa-ice-rink-must-forgo-honor-hosting-nhl-preseason-game|publisher=WHQR|accessdate=August 4, 2017|date=August 3, 2017}} ===2018 season=== For 2018, the East vs. West theme that began in 2014 was discontinued. Instead in each contest, four finalists were selected from the pool of nominations to compete in the final round of voting.{{cite web | url=https://www.krafthockeyville.ca/#how_it_works | title=Kraft Hockeyville Canada: How It Works | accessdate=January 27, 2018}}{{cite web | url=https://www.krafthockeyville.com/#how_it_works | title=Kraft Hockeyville USA: How It Works | accessdate=January 27, 2018}} The four Canadian finalists were [[High River, Alberta]], [[Huntingdon, Quebec]], [[Lafleche, Saskatchewan]], and [[Lucan Biddulph|Lucan, Ontario]]. Lucan was named the Canadian winner on March 31, 2018, and awarded a prize of C$250,000 to upgrade [[Lucan Community Memorial Centre]].{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/london/lucan-kraft-hockeyville-1.4601495 | title=Lucan wins! Kraft Hockeyville is coming to town | publisher=CBC News | date=April 1, 2018}} The pre-season game in Lucan was played between the [[Ottawa Senators]] and the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] on September 18.{{cite news | url=https://www.sportsnet.ca/hockey/nhl/maple-leafs-senators-play-kraft-hockeyville-2018/ | title=Maple Leafs and Senators to play at Kraft Hockeyville 2018 | work=Sportsnet | date=April 19, 2018}} The four USA finalists were [[Brandon, South Dakota]], [[Clinton, Oneida County, New York|Clinton, New York]], [[Middlebury, Vermont]], and [[Shreveport, Louisiana]]. Clinton was named the USA winner on April 14, 2018, and awarded a prize of US$150,000 to upgrade [[Clinton Arena]].{{cite news | url=https://www.nhl.com/news/clinton-ny-kraft-hockeyville-usa-2018/c-297994172 | title=Clinton, N.Y., named Kraft Hockeyville USA 2018 | publisher=National Hockey League | date=April 14, 2018}} The pre-season game in Clinton was between the [[Columbus Blue Jackets]] and the [[Buffalo Sabres]] on September 25.{{cite news | url=https://www.nhl.com/news/buffalo-columbus-set-for-hockeyville-game-in-clinton-ny/c-298677594?tid=280033638 | title=Sabres, Blue Jackets to play in Kraft Hockeyville USA game | publisher=National Hockey League | date=May 18, 2018}} ===2019 season=== The four Canadian finalists were [[Renous, New Brunswick]], [[Rich Valley, Alberta]], [[Saint-Polycarpe, Quebec]], and [[Wilkie, Saskatchewan]]. Renous was named the Canadian winner on March 30, and awarded a prize of C$250,000 to upgrade Tom Donovan Arena.{{cite news |title=Hockeyville win 'overwhelming' for small N.B. town |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/renous-nb-2019-hockeyville-1.5078805 |accessdate=April 8, 2019 |work=CBC News |date=March 31, 2019}} As Tom Donovan Arena was judged too small to host an NHL game, [[K. C. Irving Regional Centre]] in [[Bathurst, New Brunswick]] instead hosted the [[Florida Panthers]] and the [[Montreal Canadiens]] on September 18.{{cite press release | url=https://www.nhl.com/news/montreal-florida-will-meet-in-2019-hockeyville-canada/c-306841300 | title=Montreal Canadiens and Florida Panthers to Face Off at 2019 Kraft Hockeyville Canada on September 18 | publisher=National Hockey League | date=April 17, 2019 | accessdate=April 17, 2019}}{{cite news | url=https://959sunfm.com/2019/07/18/renous-kraft-hockeyville-game-will-be-played-in-bathurst/ | title=Renous Kraft Hockeyville game will be played in Bathurst | publisher=[[CHHI-FM|CHHI-FM (95.9 Sun FM)]] | accessdate=August 5, 2019}} The four USA finalists were [[Cadillac, Michigan]], [[Calumet, Michigan]], [[Eagle River, Wisconsin]], and [[Sartell, Minnesota]]. Calumet was named the USA winner on March 31, and awarded a prize of US$150,000 to upgrade the [[Calumet Colosseum]].{{cite news |title=Calumet Colosseum named Hockeyville USA winner |url=https://mihockey.com/2019/03/calumet-colosseum-named-hockeyville-usa-winner/ |accessdate=April 1, 2019 |work=MiHockey |date=March 31, 2019}} The Colosseum hosted the [[St. Louis Blues]] and the [[Detroit Red Wings]] on September 26.{{cite press release | url=https://www.nhl.com/news/detroit-st-louis-to-play-in-kraft-hockeyville-usa-game/c-306814368 | title=Red Wings, Blues to play in Kraft Hockeyville USA game | publisher=National Hockey League | date=April 16, 2019 | accessdate=April 17, 2019}} ==List of winners/pre-season games== {{small|Bolded teams denote winners}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size: 95%;text-align: center;" |- ! revision.text:
{{Infobox character | colour = Blue | name = Malektronic Rocketman | image = Malektronic rocketman A01.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = Rocketman giving his favorite gesture | first = 2015 | creator = Ben Malek | portrayer = Undisclosed SuperFans | voice = Rocketman does not talk | alias = {{plain list| * Tampa Bay Lighting Astronaut * Lighting Astronaut * TB Astronaut * Astro * Tampa Bay Astro }} | occupation = {{plain list| * Malektronic Mascot * Lighting SuperFan }} | nationality = American }}
'''Malektronic Rocketman''' is an astronaut used as the mascot for Malektronic LLC. The Rocketman is also known as [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] Astronaut, Lighting Astronaut, and TB Astronaut.
The Rocketman came to fame during the [[2014–15 NHL season]] with main appearances occurring during the [[2015 Stanley Cup playoffs]]. Rocketman has also appeared in numerous news broadcasts and on ESPN's flagship show SportsCenter.<ref>{{Cite web|title = ESPN helps Lightning ‘astronaut’ reach for the stars|url = http://www.tbo.com/sports/lightning/lightning-astronaut-to-appear-today-on-espn-telecasts-20150514/|website = TBO.com|access-date = 2016-01-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Tampa Bay Lightning "mascot" visits ESPN - ESPN Front Row|url = http://www.espnfrontrow.com/2015/05/tampa-bay-lightning-mascot-visits-espn/|website = ESPN Front Row|access-date = 2016-01-27|language = en-US|first = Kate|last = Rosen}}</ref>
==Creation== Rocketman was created by Malektronic CEO Ben Malek. Rocketman was originally part of a marketing campaign in partnership with the [[Tampa Bay Lightning]]. Malektronic speakers were given away at the game by Rocketman. After one of the speaker give aways at a [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] game Ben decided to have the Rocketman sit in one of his glass side seats. It was shortly after when people started to notice and post pictures and questions on social media about it.
==History== The Malektronic Rocketman (Astronaut) was originally seen at the [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] vs [[Los Angeles Kings|L.A. Kings]] on February 7, 2015. However, Rocketman gained more nationwide exposure at a subsequent game on March 25, 2014 where the [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] played the [[Florida Panthers]]. The video and images from that game started the Rocketman on a viral social journey that would last all the way into and through the [[2015 Stanley Cup playoffs]] and well into the start of the [[2015–16 NHL season]].
==Actors== More than one person has worn the Rocketman suit. Depending on the event they are attending there may be more than one actor donning the suit.
==Superfan vs Marketing Ploy== There has been debate over the novelty of the Rocketman. The original social belief on the sight of an astronaut at hockey games was that it was a superfan. Latter many news agencies thought they were exposing<ref>{{Cite web|title = Truth behind Astronaut Guy at Lightning games - Sportsnet.ca|url = http://www.sportsnet.ca/hockey/nhl/astronaut-tampa-bay-lightning-glass-ad-speaker-malektronic-viral-playoffs/|website = Sportsnet.ca|access-date = 2016-01-28|language = en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Lightning astronaut mascot isn't some superfan, just marketing|url = https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/nhl-puck-daddy/the-lightning-astronaut-mascot-isn-t-some-superfan--just-marketing-201824936.html|website = Yahoo Sports|access-date = 2016-01-28}}</ref> Rocketman by reporting its "just" some company.
While Malektronic will not deny the use of an astronaut at the games was part of some fun marketing they will still swear the superfan aspect is valid. Most of Malektronic’s employees are dedicated [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] fans and Malektronic CEO Ben Malek is a big fan of the [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] fan where he is a long time season ticket holder and a Suite owner. Some fans even bestow the "Superfan" title on Ben.
==The Chicago Connection== During the 2014-2015 Stanley Cup Championship there became an interesting twist. Rocketman was attending all home games during the Championships. Once it came down to [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] vs [[Chicago Blackhawks]] some social media and news sources found out CEO Ben Malek used to be a die hard Chicago fan.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Chicago's connection to the Tampa Bay Lightning astronaut|url = http://www.redeyechicago.com/sports/redeye-tampa-bay-lightning-astronaut-20150602-story.html|website = redeyechicago.com|access-date = 2016-01-28|last = RedEye}}</ref> Ben assured Tampa fans and friends he and Rocketman were still behind Tampa Bay 100% in the playoffs.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://malektronic.com/Rocketman/ Official Malektronic Rocketman Website]
{{Tampa Bay Lightning}}

revision.text:
Players in the '''[[National Hockey League]]''' wear equipment which allows their team affiliation to be easily identified, unifying the image of the team. Currently, a NHL uniform consists of a [[hockey jersey]], [[hockey pants]], [[hockey sock|socks]], gloves, and a [[Hockey helmet#Helmets in the National Hockey League|helmet]].
==Background== Historically, the only standardized piece of the equipment has been the sweater (jersey), which has to be of identical design by the same company for all members of a team. Other elements merely have a number scheme, allowing individual players to select their own brand and model colored to match the uniform but not necessarily identical in appearance. [[Ice hockey stick|Sticks]] and other equipment worn under the clothes have no requirements in terms of matching a team's colors; teams will sometimes provide players with team-brand [[undershirts]] or other under-clothing, but players are not required or limited to wearing them.
[[Goaltender|Goalies]] often have their pads and gloves and masks colored to match the team's color scheme, but there is no requirement for this equipment to match, and goalies who transfer to a new team often play in their old equipment until new colors can be obtained. Alternatively, players who transfer teams have sometimes had their gloves painted temporarily to match the required colors, and are given new helmets.
Each team is currently required to have two sweater designs: One with a white base (or historically, a yellow color), and one with a darker-colored base. Between the 1970-71 and 2002-03 seasons, NHL teams wore white (or yellow) uniforms at home and dark uniforms on the road (which is the current convention in some low-level ice hockey leagues). Since the 2003–04 season, NHL teams typically wear the dark color at home and the white for road games; there are occasional single-game exceptions.<ref>When third sweaters are worn, there are occasions when a team requests to wear their third sweater, whose color requires that game to use opposite home/away colors.</ref><ref>[http://coyotes.nhl.com/team/app?articleid=337397&page=NewsPage&service=page Phoenix Coyotes 2007-08 "Reverse Jersey Nights"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080315113028/http://coyotes.nhl.com/team/app?articleid=337397&page=NewsPage&service=page |date=March 15, 2008 }}</ref><ref>[http://kings.nhl.com/team/app/?service=page&page=NHLPage&id=31734 Los Angeles Kings Uniform History] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090512200754/http://kings.nhl.com/team/app/?service=page&page=NHLPage&id=31734 |date=2009-05-12 }}</ref> The only element allowed by NHL rules to be interchangeable between the two sets of equipment is the pants.
===Third Sweater Program=== Starting in 1995 (excluding a few prior isolated instances), some teams began to design a [[Third sweater#National Hockey League|third sweater]], or alternate sweater, which allowed them to experiment with new designs, or throwback to a vintage design. Though they are termed third sweaters, they can actually entail an entirely separate look from the primary equipment, often including alternate socks, and sometimes alternate helmets and other equipment.<ref>For example, the early 2000s [[New York Rangers]] Liberty-head third sweater was a different blue than the team's road sweater, requiring alternate socks, helmets and other color-matched equipment.</ref> Some third sweaters have eventually become the bases for new primary sweater designs.
Third sweaters are typically worn only a few times a season by special permission of the league, based on a list of requested games. They can also be worn during selected playoff games. The third sweater program, as the NHL came to call it, was temporarily suspended on two occasions: for the 2007–08 season (due to logistics problems with the introduction of the Reebok Edge sweater that was unveiled at the [[2007 NHL All-Star Game]]) and for the 2017–18 season (due to the introduction of the Adidas sweater).
A team's desire to wear their third sweater sometimes requires the opposing team to wear their home or road sweater when the opposite would be normally worn, due to the color of the third sweater. This can occur when a road team wishes to wear a colored third sweater, or a home team wishes to wear a white third sweater, as there must be one team each wearing white and colored uniforms in a game. This can require a team to carry two sets of uniforms and equipment on the road, whether they are using their third sweaters, or are playing against a team who is. As of the 2018-19 season, the [[New Jersey Devils]] (sweater modeled after the home sweater the team wore from 1982 to 1992) are the only team to wear a white third sweater. The [[Washington Capitals]] (2011 Winter Classic sweater modeled after the sweater the team wore from 1974 to 1995) were the only NHL team to have a white third sweater from the 2011-12 season to the 2014-15 season, when they were replaced by red sweaters of the same design. The [[Philadelphia Flyers]] used a special white third sweater for their 50th anniversary in the 2016–17 season.
==Sweaters== As hockey originates as an outdoor winter sport where players wore sweaters, this terminology has been retained to describe what is probably the most recognized element of a team's equipment (which is the only element which is mass marketed to the public).
Most NHL sweaters (jerseys) display the team's primary [[logo]] in the center of the chest, while some also display secondary logos on the shoulders. Each player in a team's lineup for a game must have a different [[Squad number#Ice hockey|number]] displayed on the back of their sweater, as well as the player's surname above their number on the back of their sweater. While not required, teams typically place their numbers on each upper arm as well. Team [[Captain (hockey)|captains]] and alternate captains wear the letters "C" and "A" respectively on the front of their sweaters. Sweaters have a loop of fabric sewn into the inside back, called a "fight strap" or "tie-down", which must be secured to the player's pants during a game, to prevent the sweater from being pulled over the player's head in a fight. Players normally get a new jersey every ten or so games, although due to other reasons players may get another jersey sooner.
In recent years, teams have sold both "pro" model sweaters, ostensibly identical to those worn by players, and "replica" quality sweaters which are cheaper versions that typically use cheaper production methods and lower-quality materials. Replica versions typically lack the fight strap, and in recent years have an additional brand logo on the left wrist.
===History=== Prior to 2000, different NHL teams had contracts with different manufacturers for their sweaters, although in some years all or most teams had a deal with one supplier. Manufacturers included [[CCM (The Hockey Company)|CCM]], [[Koho (company)|Koho]], [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]], [[Starter (clothing line)|Starter]], and [[Fruit of the Loom|Pro Player]].
====2000–07==== From the 2000–01 season, up to the 2005–06 NHL season, all team sweaters were made by The Hockey Company in an NHL-wide deal, and were branded with subsidiary brands. The [[Koho (company)|Koho]] brand was on dark sweaters and third sweaters, while the [[CCM (The Hockey Company)|CCM]] brand was on the white sweaters. The Hockey Company began the practice of putting the manufacturer's logo on the back of the sweater, below the neck, rather than on the back of the waist hem, as had previously been the practice. [[Jofa]], another subsidiary, made the sweaters for referees and linesmen until the 2005–06 season, when they were re-branded CCM which they remain as of 2008–09.
Following [[Reebok]]'s purchase of The Hockey Company, all official NHL team sweaters were switched to the Reebok (Rbk Hockey) brand (which is more familiar to the general public), while cheaper replica sweaters sold to fans retained the CCM branding. Reebok logos are on the side boards in all NHL arenas (for marketing purposes) just above the blue and red lines.
====2007-2017: Reebok Edge{{anchor|RbkEdge}}==== <!-- This section is wikilinked from [[2009 NHL Winter Classic]] --> The ''Rbk Edge'', or simply ''Edge'', is a newer line of sweaters designed by [[Reebok]]. They were announced by Reebok after nearly three years of development.<ref>{{cite news | last = Coffey | first = Phil | coauthors = | title = Players will have the EDGE in 2006–07 | work = | pages = | publisher = NHL.com | date = 2007-01-22 | url = http://corporate.reebok.com/en/news/press_releases/rbk_edge_uniform.asp?mode=print& | accessdate = 2007-01-22 }}</ref> The new<!-- AWB: not caps --> sweaters are tighter-fitting, are less water-absorbent, and are more flexible than before.<ref>{{cite press release | title = Reebok And NHL To Unveil New Technologically-advanced Uniform System | publisher = Reebok Hockey | date = 2007-01-22 | url = http://en.rbkhockey.com/news/read.php?pr_id=254 | accessdate = 2007-01-22 }} {{Dead link|date=March 2010}}</ref> It was intended to make players more maneuverable on the ice. The Edge sweaters were unveiled at the [[55th National Hockey League All-Star Game]] and began to be worn, league-wide, from the [[2007–08 NHL season]] onwards. Almost every team in the league made at least minor changes to their equipment design in conjunction with implementing the new sweater style. The [[San Jose Sharks]], [[Tampa Bay Lightning]], [[Ottawa Senators]], [[Vancouver Canucks]], [[Dallas Stars]], and [[Washington Capitals]] redesigned their equipment altogether with a new or updated logo. The [[Columbus Blue Jackets]] and [[Minnesota Wild]] used their [[third sweater|alternate sweater]] from the previous three seasons as the basis for their new look, complete with the team adopting the alternate logo from their alternates as their primary logo.
Five of the [[Original Six]] teams (excluding the [[Boston Bruins]]) as well as the [[New Jersey Devils]] kept their previous styles intact when possible, with the Devils going as far as to issue a [[press release]] saying that the team had no plans for an event unveiling the Rbk Edge design, because there was nothing new to see.<ref>[http://nhluniforms.com/TwoThousands.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228155500/http://nhluniforms.com/TwoThousands.html |date=February 28, 2009 }}</ref> The [[Anaheim Ducks]] and [[Buffalo Sabres]], who both had just redesigned their sweaters the year before the implementation of the Edge sweaters, also left theirs mostly unchanged. But the Sabres made the logo on the front of their sweater smaller and took away the silver outline on their white away sweater, and the Ducks added orange piping to their sweater's neckline.
Along with the traditional differences between the replica and authentic versions of NHL sweaters, the replica (billed as "premier") versions of the Edge sweater sold to the public have a "jock tag" on the left side of the front near the waist with the Reebok vector, NHL logo, and sweater size.
Citing player complaints, Reebok later modified the Edge sweaters, removing the play-dry material in the front and making the sleeves bigger. The modified sweaters, dubbed the ''Edge II'', made their debut at the [[2008 NHL Winter Classic]] on January 1, 2008. On that occasion, the participating Buffalo Sabres and Pittsburgh Penguins both used throwback designs for the jerseys.<ref> {{cite news |last = Pollina |first = Erin |title = Gearing Up For The NHL Winter Classic |publisher = Sabres.com |date = 2007-12-21 |url = http://sabres.nhl.com/club/news.htm?bcid=347420 |accessdate = 2009-12-31 |url-status = dead |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110807193410/http://sabres.nhl.com/club/news.htm?bcid=347420 |archivedate = 2011-08-07 }}</ref>
====2017–present: Adidas ADIZERO==== In 2015, the NHL and [[Adidas]] announced plans for Adidas to begin manufacturing official NHL jerseys starting in the 2017–18 season. All jerseys are owned by the NHL. On June 20, 2017, the NHL unveiled new ADIZERO sweaters for each of the 31 teams, including the first uniform for the league's newest team, the [[Vegas Golden Knights]]. The new sweaters are advertised as being lighter, cooler, and stronger than previous jerseys. <ref>{{cite news | last = Public Relations | first = NHL | title = NHL, adidas unveil uniforms | publisher = NHL Public Relations | date = June 20, 2017|url=https://www.nhl.com/news/nhl-jerseys-by-adidas-unveiled-for-2017-18-season/c-290020400 | accessdate = June 20, 2017 }}</ref> Due to the change, there were no third "alternate" jerseys for any NHL teams for the 2017–18 season. When the third jersey program resumed the next season, teams were given the option of wearing either one-off "Heritage" alternates (normally throwback designs of past sweaters), full-time third jerseys, or both.
As of 2020, the NHL is the only one of the four [[major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada|major professional American sports leagues]] whose uniforms are not outfitted by [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]]. However, Nike did outfit a few NHL teams in the past, most notably with the [[Edmonton Oilers]] during the [[Wayne Gretzky]] era, and during the late 1990s for a few select teams.
==Other equipment== {{unreferenced section|date=April 2013}} A team's gear also includes color requirements for other equipment, while not requiring players to use a specific brand or model, so they may select equipment to their preferences. This includes a player's gloves, pants, and helmet. Socks are also part of the design, historically with some pattern of horizontal stripes. CCM/Reebok has been a frequent supplier of player equipment and skates.
There is a sock and pant design by Reebok with similar technological improvements and design intentions.
==See also== {{Portal|Sports|Fashion}} * [[Ice hockey equipment]] * [[Sportswear (activewear)]]

page.title: Race and ethnicity in the NHL

revision.text:
The [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) evolved from a [[mono-ethnic]] and primarily Canadian professional athletic league to span North America.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1999/10/04/267567/soAccoul-on-ice-a-growing-number-of-black-players-are-making-their-mark-in-a-league-that-until-recently-has-been-known-for-its-insensitivity|title=Soul On Ice: Black players in the NHL|first=Michael|last=Farber|publisher=[[Sports Illustrated]]|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=s-CCfJ8WkJEC&pg=PA96&lpg=PA96&dq=ice%20hockey%20white%20sport&source=bl&ots=3zsy4A6T7X&sig=uywtQdXZ5nb74EEGLyQbvi6RiU4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjz-PL24-PQAhVMBcAKHa55Arg4ChDoAQhXMAQ#v=onepage&q=ice%20hockey%20white%20sport&f=false|title=NBC's Portrayal of U.S. and Canadian Hockey Players on the Olympic Stage: A Textual Analysis of Gender, Race, and Nationality Issues in the Commentary|date=1 January 2008|publisher=ProQuest|accessdate=8 December 2016|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=sI6eBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA63&lpg=PA63&dq=ice%20hockey%20white%20sport&source=bl&ots=NFUnUqe9ZB&sig=DWnMK6L0loeQaOZI9pxHKDkKzGs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjz-PL24-PQAhVMBcAKHa55Arg4ChDoAQhUMAM#v=onepage&q=ice%20hockey%20white%20sport&f=false|title=An Illustrated History of Health and Fitness, from Pre-History to our Post-Modern World|first=Roy J.|last=Shephard|date=27 November 2014|publisher=Springer|accessdate=8 December 2016|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.habseyesontheprize.com/2014/3/28/5493088/the-history-of-black-players-in-the-nhl|title=Being black in the NHL|first=Matt|last=Drake|date=28 March 2014|publisher=[[SB Nation]]|accessdate=7 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9ysEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA32&lpg=PA32&dq=african%20americans%20boston%20bruins%20ice%20hockey&source=bl&ots=JfnmGlVa8d&sig=xrWlLiC_92BC00NRDgXxkUeH6sg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj-odmU2t7QAhWkA8AKHUn6CNc4ChDoAQg4MAg#v=onepage&q=african%20americans%20boston%20bruins%20ice%20hockey&f=false|title=Vibe|first=Vibe Media|last=Group|date=1 March 1994|publisher=Vibe Media Group|accessdate=6 December 2016|via=Google Books}}</ref> The distribution of ethnic groups has been gradually changing since the inception of the NHL.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://is.muni.cz/th/382652/ff_b/BA_Thesis.pdf |format=PDF |title=Masaryk University Faculty of Arts : Department of English and American Studies |website=Is.muni.cz |accessdate=2016-11-28}}</ref> The league consists of a variety of players from varying nationalities and diverse backgrounds. Once known as a league riddled with racism and exclusiveness, the NHL has made positive steps toward a more diverse and inclusive institution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-04-01/sports/sp-877_1_black-hockey|title=Blacks and Hockey Maintain a Tenuous Relationship|first=DAVE|last=SELL|date=1 April 1990|publisher=|accessdate=7 December 2016|via=LA Times}}</ref>
According to statistics,<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.quanthockey.com/TS/TS_PlayerNationalities.php |title=NHL Nationality Breakdown |website=QuantHockey.com |date= |accessdate=2016-10-21}}</ref> gathered by www.quanthockey.com, the NHL began its expansion of player nationalities in the 1970s, where players hailed from the United States, Sweden, and Finland. The share of Canadians in the league dropped to 75% by the 1980s and is now slightly less than 50%.<ref name="auto"/> In 2011, the NHL was composed of 93% of players who identified as white, with the remaining 7% identifying as varying ethnicities.<ref name="wsbtv.com">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.wsbtv.com/news/thrashers-top-nhl-with-highest-percentage-of-black/241852512 |title=Thrashers Top NHL With Highest Percentage Of Black Players |publisher=WSB-TV |date= |accessdate=2016-10-21}}</ref>{{Update inline|date=April 2018}}
==History== A number of ice hockey leagues for players of African descent formed in Canada as early as the late-19th century. The [[Coloured Hockey League]] was an all-black ice hockey league established in 1895. Operating across the [[The Maritimes|Maritime provinces]] of Canada, the league operated for several decades until 1930.
Although other ice hockey leagues saw integration in the early 20th century (including the [[Quebec Senior Hockey League]]), the NHL did not see its first non-white player until March 13, 1948, when [[Larry Kwong]] broke the NHL's colour barrier playing with the [[New York Rangers]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ward|first1=Rachel|title=NHL trailblazer Larry Kwong dies at 94|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/larry-kwong-calgary-nhl-1.4582793|publisher=''[[CBC News]]''|accessdate=19 March 2018|language=en|date=19 March 2018}}</ref> Born in [[Vernon, British Columbia]], Kwong was a [[Chinese Canadian]] of [[Cantonese people|Cantonese]] descent.<ref>NHL, [http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=377919 "CBC targets Chinese hockey fans with Mandarin broadcasts of NHL playoffs"], Canadian Press, 2008 April 20</ref> In 1953, [[Fred Sasakamoose]] was the first [[Cree]] NHL player, and the first Canadian [[Indigenous peoples in Canada|indigenous]] player in the NHL, debuting with the [[Chicago Blackhawks|Chicago Black Hawks]]. On January 18, 1958, [[Willie O'Ree]] became the first [[Black Canadian]] to play in the NHL. Playing with the [[Boston Bruins]], he was also the first NHL player of African-descent.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Harris |first1=Cecil |title=Breaking the Ice: The Black Experience in Professional Hockey |date=2003 |publisher=Insomniac Press |location=Toronto |isbn=1897415052 |page=20 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8E74agb2dk4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=nhl+%22willie+o%27ree%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj4gavFqtnYAhUa0IMKHT8KAKkQ6AEINjAD#v=onepage&q=nhl%20%22willie%20o'ree%22&f=false |accessdate=2018-01-15}}</ref>
[[Val James]] was the first [[African American]] player to play in the NHL. James signed his contract with the [[Buffalo Sabres]] in 1982.<ref name="Black American NHL Player 2015">"IAs First Black American NHL Player, Enforcer Was Defenseless Vs. Racism." All Things Considered 26 Feb. 2015. General OneFile. Web. 10 July 2016.</ref> His stint with the Buffalo Sabres and [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] were short lived and he eventually retired in 1987 due to injury.<ref name="Black American NHL Player 2015"/> He experienced racism as the first player throughout his skating career. He never spoke of racism on the ice until 30 years after his career ended. In his account, he reported he could not watch hockey games for 10 years after leaving the ice without being haunted by the memories of his treatment as a man of color in the NHL.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nhl/story/_/page/blackhistoryNHL1/nhl-pioneer-val-james-not-bitter-tortured-playing-days |title=NHL - Pioneer Val James not bitter about his tortured playing days |website=Espn.com |date=2015-02-14 |accessdate=2016-10-21}}</ref>. A biography of his life in the sport was published under the title ''Black Ice: The Val James Story'' written by John Gallagher.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/04/sports/hockey/val-james-first-us-born-black-player-in-nhl-publishes-autobiography.html|title=Val James First US Born Black Player in NHL Publishes Autobiography|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2016-10-22}}</ref> The number of black NHL players moved to 26 by the end of the 20th century and sat at 32 in 2016. This is a seemingly minor yet significant change in the racial demographic of the NHL in its hundred-year history.<ref name="wsbtv.com"/>
In addition to black and white players, other races and ethnicities represented in the NHL (in the [[2017–18 NHL season|2017–18]] season) include players of [[Middle Eastern]]-descent (including [[Brandon Saad]], [[Justin Abdelkader]], [[Mika Zibanejad]], and [[Nazem Kadri]]), players of [[Latino]]-descent (including [[Al Montoya]], [[Auston Matthews]], [[Max Pacioretty]], and [[Raffi Torres]]), and players of [[Asian people|Asian]]-descent (including [[Kailer Yamamoto]], and [[Matthew Dumba]]).
==See also== *[[Baseball color line]] *[[Black players in ice hockey]] **[[List of black NHL players]] *[[Black players in professional American football]] *[[History of African Americans in the Canadian Football League]] *[[Race and ethnicity in the NBA]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
The following is a list of the all-time standings records for each of the 31 active [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) teams, beginning with the first NHL season ([[1917–18 NHL season|1917–18]]), and accurate as of the end of the [[2015–16 NHL season]].<ref name=HRallteams>{{cite web|url=https://www.hockey-reference.com/teams/|title=NHL Teams & Other Hockey Teams|publisher=Sports Reference|work=Hockey-Reference|accessdate=January 6, 2017}}</ref> Teams are sorted by the overall percentage of points accumulated out of points available (two times the number of games played) throughout NHL history. In the NHL's standings system, a team is awarded 2 points for a win (regardless if earned in regulation or [[overtime (sports)|overtime]]), 1 point for a [[tie (draw)#Ice hockey|tie]], 1 point for an overtime loss, and 0 points for a loss.<ref name=Silver2015>{{cite news|author-link=Nate Silver|last=Silver|first=Nate|url=http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/a-radical-proposal-to-destroy-the-nhls-loser-point/|title=A Radical Proposal To Destroy The NHL's Loser Point|work=FiveThirtyEight|date=April 2, 2015|accessdate=January 6, 2017}}</ref>
The overtime loss statistic (abbreviated as OT or OTL) was introduced into the NHL's standings in the [[1999–2000 NHL season|1999–2000 season]].<ref>{{cite web|last=McIndoe|first=Sean|url=http://grantland.com/features/at-a-loss/|title=At a Loss|publisher=Grantland|date=January 14, 2014|accessdate=January 6, 2017}}</ref> The term for the point in standings awarded to a team for an overtime loss is the ''Bettman point'',<ref name=Dictionary>{{cite web|last=McIndoe|first=Sean|url=http://grantland.com/features/sean-mcindoe-nhl-grantland-dictionary/#bettmanpoint|title=Grantland Dictionary: NHL Edition|publisher=Grantland|date=January 14, 2014|accessdate=January 6, 2017}}</ref> named after [[Gary Bettman]], the [[NHL commissioner]] at the time of its introduction.<ref>{{cite news|last=McCurdy|first=Bruce|url=https://edmontonjournal.com/sports/hockey/nhl/cult-of-hockey/nhl-delivers-yet-another-gimmick-for-overtime-but-once-again-fails-to-address-the-real-problem|title=NHL delivers yet another gimmick for overtime, but once again fails to address the real problem|newspaper=Edmonton Journal|date=June 24, 2015|accessdate=January 6, 2017}}</ref> It is more commonly referred to as a ''loser point'' by media outlets and fans alike.<ref name=Silver2015/><ref name=Dictionary/>
As a result of the [[2004–05 NHL lockout]], which canceled the entire [[2004–05 NHL season|2004–05 season]], the league adopted a shootout featuring shots on goals, in order to determine the winner of a game which is still tied after an overtime period.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/opinion/editorials/2005-10-05-nhl-edit_x.htm|title=Fit to be tied|newspaper=USA Today|date=October 5, 2005|accessdate=January 6, 2017}}</ref> This adoption, introduced in the [[2005–06 NHL season|2005–06 season]], eliminated ties from the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/page.htm?id=26395|title=NHL Adopts Shootout|website=National Hockey League|date=July 22, 2005|accessdate=January 6, 2017}}</ref>
==Regular season== [[File:Montreal Canadiens.svg|thumb|Logo of the Montreal Canadiens, the NHL leader in terms of games (tied with Toronto Maple Leafs), wins, ties, points, and point percentage, as of the end of the 2016–17 season.]] [[File:OliverEkmanLarsson2.jpg|thumb|Oliver Ekman-Larsson of the Arizona Coyotes, the team with the lowest point percentage in NHL history, as of the end of the 2017–18 season.]] As of the end of 2016–17 NHL season, the [[Montreal Canadiens]] and [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] are tied for the most games played in the NHL, with 6,578 games.<ref name=HRallteams/> The Canadiens additionally lead all NHL franchises in wins (3,374), ties (837), and points (7,732).<ref name=HRallteams/> The Maple Leafs additionally lead all NHL franchises in losses (2,762).<ref name=HRallteams/> Being the most recently established team in the NHL, the [[Vegas Golden Knights]] have the fewest games played among all NHL franchises (164).<ref name=HRallteams/> The Vegas Golden Knights also have the fewest wins (94), and points (202). The Arizona Coyotes have the lowest point percentage in NHL history (.477).<ref name=HRallteams/> The Vegas Golden Knights have the fewest total losses (56).<ref name=HRallteams/> In terms of overtime losses, the [[Florida Panthers]] have recorded the most (181), while the Vegas Golden Knights have recorded the fewest (14).<ref name=HRallteams/>

==Playoffs== [[File:Wayne Gretzky statue 6.jpg|thumb|Statue of Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oilers, who have the second highest playoff winning percentage in NHL history.]] [[File:Nathan Horton - Columbus Blue Jackets.jpg|thumb|Nathan Horton of the Columbus Blue Jackets in 2014, who have the lowest playoff winning percentage in NHL history.]] The [[Stanley Cup Playoffs]] predate the [[National Hockey League]]'s founding, and thus for the purpose of this listing, playoffs win–loss records prior to the [[1918 Stanley Cup playoffs]], which ended the [[1917–18 NHL season]], are not accounted for. As of the end of the [[2017 Stanley Cup playoffs]], which ended the [[2016–17 NHL season]], the [[Montreal Canadiens]] lead all active NHL teams in playoffs appearances, having appeared in 83 of their 99 seasons played in the NHL,<ref name=HRallteams/> and playoff games played, with 729.<ref name=Montreal/> The Canadiens additionally lead all NHL teams in wins (422).<ref name=Montreal/> The [[Vegas Golden Knights]] lead all NHL teams, in terms of playoff winning percentage, as their 13–7 (.650) record is the highest.<ref name=Edmonton/> The [[Winnipeg Jets]], being one of the more recently established NHL teams, have the fewest playoff games played (8).<ref name=Winnipeg/> The Jets also have the lowest playoff winning percentage, having lost all eight of their playoff games, registering a .000 record.<ref name=Winnipeg/> Additionally, the [[Boston Bruins]] lead all NHL franchises in playoff losses (308).<ref name=Boston/>

page.title: List of National Hockey League longest winning streaks

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/GF|General fixes]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: occuring → occurring
revision.text:
This is a list of the longest winning streaks in [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) history. The list includes streaks that started at the end of one season and carried over into the following season. There are two lists, streaks that consist entirely of regular-season games and streaks made up of playoff games only. The [[1992–93 Pittsburgh Penguins season|Pittsburgh Penguins]] hold the record for the longest winning streak in NHL history at 17 games, which was set in the [[1992–93 NHL season|1992–93 season]]; that team won the [[Presidents' Trophy]] for having the league's best record of 56–21–7.{{cite web|url=http://mcubed.net/nhl/astrkgwp.shtml|title=NHL: Longest Winning Streaks/Regular Season Games|accessdate=November 7, 2019|work=mcubed.net}} In the [[1991–92 Pittsburgh Penguins season|previous season]], that team won a NHL-record total of 14 straight games in the [[1992 Stanley Cup playoffs|playoffs]].{{cite web|url=http://mcubed.net/nhl/astrkgwp.shtml|title=NHL: Longest Winning Streaks/Playoff Games|accessdate=November 7, 2019|work=mcubed.net}} Only regular season winning streaks lasting twelve or more games are included. The [[Montreal Canadiens]] appear six times across both lists, with four streaks over 11 games in the postseason and two streaks over 12 games or more in the regular season. The [[Boston Bruins]] appear four times across both lists, with three of those streaks over 10 games occurring in the regular season. Prior to the [[2005–06 NHL season|2005–06 season]], tie games were abolished in favor of a shootout. ==Key== {| class="wikitable" |- |style="background-color:#ffffff; width:4em" colspan=2 align=center|''Italic score'' |Denotes streak ended with a tie |- |style="background-color:#ccccff; width:4em" colspan=2 align=center|^ |Denotes streaks that spanned two seasons |- |style="background-color:#ffff66; width:4em" colspan=2 align=center| |Denotes streaks that are currently in progress |- |style="background-color:#ffffff; width:4em" colspan=2 align=center|* |Denotes season in which team won championship |} ==Streaks== ===Regular season=== This list contains only the top streaks consisting '''entirely''' of regular-season games. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%" ! rowspan="2" | Rank ! rowspan="2" | Games ! rowspan="2" | Team ! rowspan="2" | Season(s) ! rowspan="2" | Season
